unnormalised: EdTech startup, 'ShikshaForAll' secures $5M in Series A funding. The round was led by Kalaari Capital and saw participation from existing investors. Located in Bangalore, 'ShikshaForAll' aims to bridge the education gap in rural India, offering courses at just Rs. 99 per month.
normalised: EdTech startup, 'Shiksha For All' secures dollar five million in Series A funding. The round was led by Kalaari Capital and saw participation from existing investors. Located in Bangalore, 'Shiksha For All' aims to bridge the education gap in rural India, offering courses at just rupee ninety nine per month.

unnormalised: The funding will be used to expand their reach to 5000+ villages across India. Currently, they have 2 lakh+ students enrolled. ShikshaForAll's app is available on the Google Play Store and has a 4.5-star rating with 100k+ downloads.
normalised: The funding will be used to expand their reach to five thousand plus villages across India. Currently, they have two lakh plus students enrolled. Shiksha For All's app is available on the Google Play Store and has a four point five-star rating with one hundred thousand plus downloads.

unnormalised: 'This funding is a major boost to our mission,' said CEO Priya Sharma, an IIT Delhi graduate. 'We plan to add more vernacular content and incorporate AI-powered learning modules.' The company is also partnering with NGOs to provide free tablets to underprivileged students.
normalised: 'This funding is a major boost to our mission,' said C-E-O Priya Sharma, an I-I-T Delhi graduate. 'We plan to add more vernacular content and incorporate A-I-powered learning modules.' The company is also partnering with N-G-Os to provide free tablets to underprivileged students.

unnormalised: Experts believe that this investment highlights the growing potential of the EdTech sector in India. With internet penetration increasing, online learning is becoming more accessible to students in remote areas.
normalised: Experts believe that this investment highlights the growing potential of the EdTech sector in India. With internet penetration increasing, online learning is becoming more accessible to students in remote areas.

unnormalised: One parent from a village in Bihar commented, "My daughter can now learn English and Maths from home. Earlier, she had to travel 5 km to attend coaching classes. This app has made education much easier and more affordable."
normalised: One parent from a village in Bihar commented, "My daughter can now learn English and Maths from home. Earlier, she had to travel five kilometer to attend coaching classes. This app has made education much easier and more affordable."

unnormalised: ShikshaForAll plans to launch new courses in coding and digital marketing soon. They are also exploring partnerships with government schools to integrate their platform into the curriculum. The company expects to reach 1 million students by 2025.
normalised: Shiksha For All plans to launch new courses in coding and digital marketing soon. They are also exploring partnerships with government schools to integrate their platform into the curriculum. The company expects to reach one million students by two thousand and twenty five.

unnormalised: This news comes amid growing concerns over the quality of education in rural areas. With initiatives like ShikshaForAll, there is hope that technology can play a crucial role in improving learning outcomes and empowering students across India. Investors see the Edtech sector growing to $4B by FY26.
normalised: This news comes amid growing concerns over the quality of education in rural areas. With initiatives like Shiksha For All, there is hope that technology can play a crucial role in improving learning outcomes and empowering students across India. Investors see the Edtech sector growing to dollar four billion by F-Y twenty six.
